_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Nursery, Garden Center, and Farm Supply Stores

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

                                           Intermountain Farmers Association

                                                    Garland Branch

                                                 Risk Management Plan





 

Facility Policy Summary



Management and employees of Intermountain Farmers Association are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous Ammonia.  If an accidental release would occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



Organizational Chart:



  * Vice President Ag. Operations

  * Safety Manager - Responsible for RMP Program

  * Region Manager - Responsible for Agronomy centers

  * Branch Manager - Responsible for branch employees and maintenance of the RMP program

 



Facility Information



The primary activity at the facility is the storage and blending of fertilizers for retail sale to farmers.



Anhydrous Ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.



The maximum quantity stored would be 475,036 lbs in two 30,000 gallon storage tanks, two 6,000 gallon storage tanks and one rail car holding 31,040 gal. The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a rail tank car holding 160,000 pounds.





Accidental release prevention program



The facility has implemented the provisions of ASafety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by the American National Standards Institute, Inc., and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, AStorage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia@.





Five-year Accident History



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:



Have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant

property damage at the facility, nor have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.





Emergency Response Program



The facility has:

A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38.



Provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).



A written emergency response program, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions and training of employees.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
